name: Pseudo-Stamens
description: The pale wing-sheathes hiding in a Wenut's tail are as thin as the bloomingstamens of a flower.  It is said that in the past, even before the beginning of time, they used totravel through the moist land under meadows and forests, similar to birdsflying across the sky and fish swimming in the water. It is generally believedthat their mimicry of flowers is to lure lost prey caught by sandstorms. Thereis also a theory, however, that their imitation of a blooming flower wasinspired by the splendid blossoms countless epochs ago, which have long gonethe way of the desert winds.
